Hospitals and other health and human services providers periodically conduct such assessments within their service areas to guide planning and comply with government requirements. Working together in se veral committees, representatives from the three communities and service providers collected and analyzed primary and secondary data for the iCHNA . The goal was to gain a comprehensive regional understanding of needs related to health and quality of life and identif y priority concerns to help guide planning for services and potential opportunities for joint action initiatives. Issue areas that have emerged in 2019 as priorities include housing, behavioral health and substance use disorders, and economic stability and mobility. Information about the iCHNA & CHIP partners and the community outreach process can be found at www.northsuffolkassessment.org . A video summariz ing the pro cess can be found at https://youtu.be/FvSAn8dzu2A . Executive Summary Neighboring Communities Request Re gional Assessment Several hospital systems, a large community health center , and a number of other health and human services agencies serve residents of Revere, Chelsea , and Winthrop. These service providers conduct periodic assessments of community needs in order to plan accordingly for delivery of services. The Affordable Care Act also requires health care institutions to conduct CHNAs every three years in communities where they have licensed facilities to demonstrate they have engaged with local communit ies to ascertain needs, especially the needs of underserved populations within their service or catchment areas. Ordinarily , each provider conducts its own assessment --not in conjunction with other service providers. The 2019 integrated Community Health N eeds Assessment and Community Health Improvement Plan, or iCHNA and CHIP, represent a departure from the usual manner in which hospitals and other providers conduct assessments. At the request of the Mayor, City Manager , and Town Manager, of Revere, Chelse a and Winthrop, hospitals and other providers agreed to work together with the municipalities and other health stakeholders to conduct a fully collaborative assessment. This request was a natural extension of an inter -municipal collaboration created in 201 6, the North Suffolk Public Health Collaborative, so named because the three communities comprise the portion of Suffolk County that is not the City of Boston. Existing Collaborative Serves as Coordinating Entity The North Suffolk Public Health Collaborat ive (NSPHC) was created so that three adjacent communities could identify shared public health challenges and opportunities to collaborate and achieve more on selected issues than the communities might achieve working on their own . The communities share some common characteristics and while having significant differences in demographics and specific health issues. Like much of the country, all three communities have populations that have become increasingly ethnically diverse, which is an important factor f or consideration in planning for health care and human services. The NSPHC director co - North Suffolk 2019 Integrated Community Health Needs Assessment 5 coordinated the iCHNA and CHIP with a senior director at the Center for Community Health Improvement of Massachusetts General Hospital, one of the hospital system colla borators . Development of Structure and Goals The iCHNA and CHIP w ere developed through a deliberate, inclusive process, starting with the formation of a Steering Committee composed of municipal leaders and representatives of the three communities' health departments and boards of health, along with the health and human services providers and community residents. A Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) was created which the municipalities and collaborating organizations were asked to sign. Language in the MOU addressed the vision and goals of the process . iCHNA Collaborative Vision -To use the upcoming iCHNA and CHIP to work towards a North Suffolk region where : o Individuals from all backgrounds and circumstances will have every opportunity to live a healthy l ife. o Local governments, health care providers, social service and community -based organizations, and community residents work in continuous partnership to improve health outcomes for all people in the region. o Key findings developed from the iCHNA and CHIP will be provided to iCHNA collaborative organizations to aid implementation of subsequent iCHNA and CHIP initiatives. Goals of the iCHNA Collaborative : o Conduct and complete a joint, participatory iCHNA for Revere, Chelsea , and Winthrop by September 30, 201 9. o Develop a n iCHNA Collaborative CHIP for Revere, Chelsea , and Winthrop that addresses priorities and identifies opportunities for shared investment and programming by the partners for the period of 2019 -2021 . o Monitor and evaluate CHIP strategies for pr ogress and impact to continuously inform implementation . o Communicate to , and engage in the process with, municipal and organizational leadership, community stakeholders , and the public throughout the assessment, planning , and implementation period . o Create iCHNA and CHIP reports that will, at a minimum, meet IRS, Attorney General, Accountable Care Organization (ACO), Public Health Accreditation Board (PHAB), Determination of Need (DoN), and Health Resources and Services Administration (HRSA) requirements. To plan and conduct the iCHNA process through its multiple phases, the Steering Committee created several subcommittees --Instrument Review, Community Engagement, Data Analysis --and working groups were then created to develop CHIP initiatives around priorit y issues that emerged from the assessment. Throughout the entire process, participation on the various committees and in the working groups was enthusiastic and productive, which is a testament to the collaborative spirit of the participants and their comm itment to the wellbeing of residents of the three communities. Emphasis on Inclusion and Recognition of Social Determinants of Health From the outset of the iCHNA and CHIP, collaborators were determined to include the needs of population segments that ar e sometimes hidden, overlooked, marginalized , or stigmatized. Members of such groups may never present at health centers, may not feel welcome or understood when they do , or may not feel comfortable revealing information about themselves that is important to their health care. The iCHNA North Suffolk 2019 Integrated Community Health Needs Assessment 6 Instrument Review Subcommittee created a list of such population segments and conducted targeted key informant interviews and focus groups to ensure inclusion of these segments and those who work with them. The health statu s and medical conditions of patients can be directly or indirectly related to poverty, inadequate or unsafe housing, food insecurity and other social determinants of health. This is certainly true in the communities of Chelsea, Revere , and Winthrop, wh ere residents come from a wide range of income levels and degree of advantage or disadvantage. Daunting as such social determinants can be, the iCHNA working groups committed themselves to viewing population segments holistically and considering where they cou ld have an impact locally on the difficult issues affecting quality of life and health of community residents. Selecting Priorities and Next Steps After reviewing the primary and secondary data and taking into consideration impact, feasibility, and resour ces, the Steering Committee voted on the top three health concerns they felt could be address through a regional collaborative process. The health concerns that will be addressed over the next three years will be Housing, Economic Stability and Mobility, and Behavioral Health. Workings groups have been formed to set goals, objectives, and strategies, and begin action plans for each concern. A full Community Health Implementation Plan will be published later in 2019. North Suffolk 2019 Integrated Community Health Needs Assessment 7 The North Suffolk 2019 Community He alth Needs Assessment Report What is a Community Health Needs Assessment ? A community health needs assessment (CHNA) refers to the process of engaging community members, community -based organizations, hospitals, and health systems in order to improve a c ommunity's health and identify a community's strengths. In 2010, the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act was passed, which required hospitals to conduct CHNAs every three years. Additionally, the Massachusetts Attorney General publishes Community Be nefit guidelines which include CHNAs every 3 years. Although only hospitals and health systems are mandated to complete a CHNA, CHNAs should engage a range of community organizations as health status and quality of life are impacted by a variety of forces . For instance, it is impossible to tackle the clinical ramifications of poor housing quality in a community without also tackling the community's poor housing quality itself. Thus, to conduct a comprehensive and robust CHNA, diverse community participatio n is needed to accurately discern the community's health priorities and develop a strategic and thoughtful implementation plan that addresses these priorities. When hospitals and other health systems collaborate with existing community -based organizations , the combined knowledge between clinical and community spheres can be leveraged to promote healthy behaviors and lifestyles for community members in new and more efficient ways. These relationships between clinical and community organizations can also fue l more grant applications, more upstream public health action, and more reinforcement for a community -wide perspective to health. This is what the iCHNA intended to do --create an inclusive assessment process that engaged stakeholders to identify root cau ses of health concerns and address them in a collaborative manner. Healthy Community , Social Determinants of Health, and Health Equity There are many definitions of a healthy community. For some, healthy communities emphasize low rates of chronic and infe ctious diseases or low mortality and morbidity rates. For others, healthy communities are those where people have access to favorable social and emotional opportunities such as education, employment, housing, stable families , and healthcare. For the iCHNA, a healthy community is defined as one where individuals from all backgrounds and circumstances have every opportunity to live a healthy life; and where local governments, health care providers, social service and community -based organizations , and communi ty residents work in continuous partnership to improve health outcomes for all people in the region. North Suffolk 2019 Integrated Community Health Needs Assessment 8 Based on data from the 2019 Quality of Life survey, the three communities agreed on four aspects of a healthy community: access to health care, affordabl e housing, good schools , and low crime and low violence/safe neighborhoods. However, on a deeper community dive, each community had one aspect that ranked as their community's fi fth most important healthy community concern which did not make the top five h ealthy community aspects of the other two communities. For example, Chelsea's fifth most important aspect of a healthy community was access to healthy food. For Revere, the fifth most important aspect was effective city services such as water, trash, fire department , and police services. For Winthrop, their fifth most important aspect was a clean environment. This shows that , even regionally , it is difficult to create an all -encompassing definition of a healthy community. Although there is no ultimate def inition of a healthy community, viewing a community through the lens of its social determinants of health (SDoH) aids us in understanding its health status and determining what kinds of actions could be taken to improve it. SDoHs are those factors that cre ate environments that are either protective and supportive or harmful and detrimental for individuals and families to grow and age. These factors include childhood experiences, quality and affordable housing, educational opportunities, social support, inco me stability and mobility, employment opportunities, and access to healthcare services. As communities and organizations conduct CHNAs, the prominent requisites for communities to be healthier either are, or are related to, SDoHs. Health equity means tha t everyone has a fair opportunity to be as healthy as possible. This requires removing or reducing obstacles to good health such as poverty and discrimination and their consequences (including powerlessness and lack of access to good jobs with fair pay ), quality education and housing, safe environments, and health care. The iCHNA and CHIP process took into consideration the SDoH and health equity when creating data collection instruments and protocols, recruiting committee and subcommittee members and part icipants, collecting qualitative data, and reviewing best practices to address the health needs of North Suffolk residents. Establishment of the North Suffolk Public Health Collaborative in 2016 The NSPHC was created in 2016 by the chief executives of th e three adjacent communities of Revere, Chelsea , and Winthrop, which constitute the northern portion of Suffolk County. The mission of the NSPHC is to work with community stakeholders --city and town officials, municipal departments, health care and social service providers, community groups, etc. --to identify shared public health challenges and opportunities to collaborate productively on selected issues. Although the communities have significant differences in demographics and specific health issues, they also have common characteristics, offering the possibility of addressing some issues more effectively through working together rather than separately. In addition, like much of the United States, North Suffolk 2019 Integrated Community Health Needs Assessment 9 the populations of the three communities have become increas ingly ethnically diverse, an important factor for consideration in planning for health care and human services that meet evolving community needs. In drawing up the inter -municipal agreement to establish the Collaborative, the Mayor of Revere, City Man ager of Chelsea , and Town Manager of Winthrop received technical assistance from the Metropolitan Area Planning Council (MAPC), a regional planning agency serving much of Eastern Massachusetts. MAPC's areas of focus include public health and cross -jurisdic tional collaborations , and the agency continues to offer guidance to the Collaborative. To coordinate the NSPHC's activities, the three communities agreed to fund a dedicated position, the NSPHC director, who works with staff of the three municipalities, t heir boards of health and health departments, local provider organizations , and other community health -related stakeholders. The NSPHC and the Impetus for the 2019 North Suffolk Integrated Community Health Needs Assessment and Community Health Improvement Plan Several months after the NSPHC began operations, hospitals serving Revere, Chelsea , and Winthrop were gearing up to conduct their individual community health needs assessments and plan for community health improvement programming which were due to go vernment agencies in 2019. Most hospitals conduct assessments every three years to comply with federal and state requirements for community engagement and programming designed to target local needs, including those of underserved populations. The timing of the 2019 round of assessments presented a special opportunity. The Mayor, City Manager and Town Manager, of the three NSP HC communities asked the hospitals to depart from their customary practice and conduct the assessments jointly and collaboratively. Th eir intention was to develop a more comprehensive , shared understanding among all parties of the needs of all three communities and seek opportunities to work together to address them. The NSPHC director co -coordinated the year -long iCHNA and CHIP process with a senior director at the Center for Community Health Improvement of Massachusetts General Hospital, one of the collaborating hospital systems. The work of the iCHNA Steering Committee and various project subcommittees has resulted in this report and working groups which are developing goals, objectives , and proposed initiatives for collaborative involvement over the next three years and beyond. Going forward, it is anticipated that the NSPHC director will take a lead role in coordinating and convening partnering organizations around selected initiatives emerging from the working groups. North Suffolk 2019 Integrated Community Health Needs Assessment 10 The North Suffolk Region and the Communities Involved Suffolk County, Massachusetts , includes the cities of Boston, Revere, and Chelsea, and the town of Winthrop. In this report, North Suffolk refers to the latter three communities north of Boston: Revere, Chelsea, and Winthrop. Revere is a city located approximately 5 miles (8.0 km) from downtown Boston. Founded as North Chelsea in 1846, it was renamed in 1871 after the American Revolutionary War patriot Paul Revere. Revere Beach is the oldest public beach in the United States. Chelsea is a city directly across the Mystic River from the city of Boston. It is the second most densely populated city in Massachusetts behind Somerville. With a total area of just 2.21 square miles, Chelsea is the smallest city in Massachusetts in terms of total area. Chelsea is a diverse, working -class community that contains a high level of industrial activity. It is one of only three Massachusetts cities in which the majority of the population identifies as Hispanic or Latino . Winthrop is an oceanside suburban communit y situated at the north entrance to Boston Harbor, close to Logan International Airport. It is located on a peninsula, 1.6 square miles (4.2 km2) in area, connected to Revere by a narrow isthmus . Settled in 1630, Winthrop is one of the oldest communities in the United States. It is also one of the smallest and most densely populated municipalities in Massachusetts. To be effective, these plans would be: Comprehensive: Involving a full range of stakeholders, data, and a broad definition of hea lth and wellbeing to create a CHNA and CHIP that would reflect the needs of all community residents . Inclusive: Ensur ing all segments of the population would have a voice in the process, data collection, and implementation plan . Data -considered: Gathering extensive primary and secondary data on the health, wellbeing, and quality of life of residents through qualitative and quantitative methods . Collaborative: Guiding and engaging stakeholders throughout the process for sound decision making, co - learning, and transparency . In order to meet these values, the iCHNA was led by a Steering Committee . The Steering Committee was a selected group of leaders, including the chief executive s of the communit ies, a representative of each board of health, leaders of community organizations, and representatives from the five health systems that serve the area. If a key population segment was missing from the committee, specific agencies or representative s were recruited. The Steering Committee set direction and policy a nd had authority over priorities and implementation plans. The Steering Committee met every other month throughout the iCHNA and CHIP process. The meetings were listed on the iCHNA website , and subcommittee members were invited as well. A "Segment Inclus iveness and Social Determinants of Health" list ( Appendix F) was created in collaboration with the Steering Committee and the subcommittees. When reviewing membership on the subcommittees , as well as collecting primary data, this list was consulted to ensu re the iCHNA process and data collection were inclusive and representative. When planning for key informant interviews and focus groups, this list was used to identify individuals and groups to ensure that a variety of diverse individuals across sectors an d populations were included . As an incentive, respondents who were willing to provide an email address or phone number were entered into a drawing for one of six $50 supermarket gift cards. A total of 1, 827 individuals across Revere, Chelsea, and Winthrop responded to the survey. The survey was cleaned and analyzed in the statistical software, R. The data w ere stratified by community, live or work, age, sex, race, Hispanic/Latino, and foreign -born. The full quantitative analysis is available in Appendix C. 7. Focus Groups : Qualitative data were collected through key informant interviews and focus groups with the help of a small group of volunteers from partner organizations and the CCHI Evaluation Team. Volunteers were trained on facilitation and note -taking strategies in February 2019 prior to the start of qualitative data collection. Inter view and focus group guides were created for facilitators and note -takers , with standard questions regarding perceptions about the health of the community, community assets, and pressing health issues. Once trained, volunteers traveled to participating org anizations to facilitate focus groups. Key informant interviews were conducted both in person and on the phone based on facilitator and interviewee availability. Potential focus group participants and key informants were identified by the North Suffolk I ntegrated Community Health Needs Assessment Steering Committee using a segment inclusiveness worksheet to ensure that a variety of diverse individuals across multiple sectors and populations were included. A total of 22 focus groups were completed, 9 with staff and 13 with community residents, and 28 key informant interviews were conducted, resulting in a combined total of 241 people engaged through this process. Four focus groups were conducted in Spanish. Each interview/focus group lasted approximately 45 to 60 minutes. Community residents received a $15 gift card at the end of the focus groups as compensation for their time. A full list of focus groups and interviews are in Appendix B. Upon completion of all focus groups and key informant interviews, t he notes were read, reviewed, and coded to categorize the data and identify overarching, common themes. Several themes were found across all three communities, while a few additional themes were found applicable to one or two communities. The full qualitat ive analysis is available in Appendix C. 8. Public Health Data : Public health data were gathered from the U.S. Census, MA Department of Education, MA Department of Public Health, local Youth Risk Behavior Survey (YRBS), Prevention Needs Assessment (PNA), loc al police departments and community -based organizations. Limitations As with all field research, there are several data limitations to report. This assessment sought to obtain diverse participation in the community. Every effort was made to ensure bro ad distribution of the Quality of Life survey so that all groups in the community were represented. Despite the concerted community outreach effort, t he majority of survey respondents were white females . However, there was a sufficient sample within each c ommunity to allow for analysis by sub -groups (e.g. , male vs. female, Hispanic/Latino). Focus groups were conducted in the communities to obtain the perspectives of youth, parents, immigrants, and non -English speakers, who were all less likely to respond to surveys. North Suffolk 2019 Integrated Community Health Needs Assessment 20 Housing One of the strongest themes running through the quantitative and quali tative data was the concern around housing in North Suffolk. Based on the Quality of Life Survey, 36% of all respondents identified housing as a top-ten health concern. Survey respondents from Chelsea ranked housing as second among health concern s. This is in marked contrast with Chelsea's 2015 Quality of Life Survey in which housing did not appear among the top five health concern s. Survey respondents from Revere ranked housing fourth among health concern s. Similar to Chelsea, in 2015, Revere survey respon dents did not previously identify housing as a top health concern. In both the 2014 and 2019 Quality of Life Survey, Winthrop respondents did not rank housing as part of their top five health concerns; however, housing did have a change in ranking in Winth rop from #10 (2014) to #6 (2019) . The changes of how housing was ranked between 2014 to 2019 as a health priority indicates that Chelsea, Revere and Winthrop survey respondents are noticing that housing affects not only their finances and where they live, but that housing also affects their health. As one of the most intricate social determinants of health, housing issues cause a cascade of effects on individuals. The housing issue in North Suffolk, based on our secondary and primary data, can be split in to two categories: housing quality and affordab ility of housing. Housing quality pertains to the quality of life experienced by those who rent or own as well as the built housing environment. Affordable housing is related to the effects of rising housing c osts and subsequent consequence s of increased eviction rates and homelessness. Housing Quality: According to the American Community Survey (ACS) data from 2012 to 2016, approximately 38% of all housing units in Massachusetts were renter -occupied. On a de eper community dive, 76% of all housing units in Chelsea were renter -occupied, 52% of all housing in Revere were renter -occupied , and 43% of all housing units were renter -occupied compared to the 38% of Massachusetts's housing units being renter - occupied. Without stratifying the Quality of Life Survey, 54% of survey respondents stated that they are homeowners. When these results were stratified by community, 53% of Chelsea respondents are renters while the majority of respondents from Revere and Winthrop ar e homeowners (54% are homeowners in Revere , and 71% are homeowners in Winthrop). Obstacles to Treatment: There are many obstacles for community members who have substance use disorders to receive the clinical and social/emoti onal services they need : One of the most challenging obstacles is stigma. Many focus group participants and key informants from Winthrop and Revere shared that stigma forces community residents suffering with substance use disorders not to be open about t heir battles with substances. Residents will see needles or know of someone's family member who has used substances, but that individual will not admit it because they feel ashamed and prefer to keep the issues to themselves. Youth in Revere mentioned that they see individuals who do not get help, but instead mask the issue until it becomes a much bigger issue and, thus, creates more problems for the individual. Another obstacle individuals face on the road to recovery is once they have accepted that they need, or want, help, there is a shortage of accessible, affordable and available providers. Twelve percent of Chelsea survey respondents stated that they needed substance use services, but were not able to access them. Six percent of Revere respondents an d two percent of Winthrop respondents also needed substance use disorder services, but were not able to access them. Compared to 0.7% of non - Hispanic/Latino survey respondents, 24% of Hispanic/Latino survey respondents stated that they needed substance use disorder services, but could not access them. Although respondents did not have the option in the survey to say why they could not access these services, there is a huge demand for substance use disorder services that are culturally and linguistically com petent. Another obstacle individuals face when seeking treatment is the reality that these substance use issues do not occur in silos. If individuals are also experiencing homelessness , for example, and need mental health services, it is much harder to st ick to a treatment regimen. BSAS collects enrollment characteristics of individuals who are admitted, such as homelessness at enrollment. Homelessness at enrollment is defined as those who completed an intake within 14 days prior to enrollment and reported their address as being "Home, homeless." If there was no address type available within 14 days of a completed intake, or if the address type was unable to establish certain homelessness status, then homelessness was determined by what the individuals put when asked about whether they rent or own an apartment or where they slept last night. According to BSAS enrollment characteristics for fiscal year 2017, 33% of all individuals from Chelsea seeking treatment were experiencing homelessness at enrollment. 22 % of all individuals from Revere seeking treatment were experiencing homeless ness and 18% of all individuals from Winthrop seeking treatment were homeless at enrollment. Another obstacle is the intersection between substance use disorders and mental healt h. BSAS also collects information on whether individuals had prior mental health treatment. Thirty -nine percent of Chelsea residents enrolled for substance use disorders treatment had prior mental health treatment. Thirty -nine percent of Revere residents e nrolled for substance use disorders treatment had prior mental health treatment. Forty -seven percent of Winthrop residents enrolled for substance use disorders treatment in Chelsea had prior mental health treatment. Our health and social services providers, community officials, staff members of municipal departments and other collaborators always kept the wellbeing of the three communities' residents first and foremost in their sights as they worked together over a full year's time to conduct the assessment. We are grateful to everyone who touched this process and enhanced the results. In planning and cond ucting the iCHNA, we strove to be inclusive of the diverse segments of our communities both in establishing the committees that carried out the work and in our outreach to gather accurate, useful data about our residents. We believe the iCHNA and the CHIP priority issues that emerged are reflective of our strong community engagement. In this 2019 assessment, w e found via primary data collection that economic insecurity and housing cost issues are among our communities' highest areas of concern . This is supported by the secondary data for the communities. This is des pite frequent national news reports of record stock market highs and low unemployment rates. Many residents are working but still not able to keep up with the costs of living. A third area of concern is behavioral health, particularly substance use disorde rs and youth mental health. These concerns are almost identical with those found through a similar community health needs assessment being conducted in 2019 within the City of Boston. As mentioned earlier in this report, the municipal executives of Revere , Chelsea and Winthrop - the Mayor, City Manager and Town Manager - touched off the iCHNA in Spring 2018 when they requested that area health care providers conduct their upcoming assessments jointly for the first time. In addition to the initial spur of t his request, the CHIP will benefit from a new motivation for continuing collaboration over the next three years and beyond. The CHIP will create opportunities to identify 'low hanging fruit' initiatives that can be implemented immediately with few resource s, as well as initiatives needing funding to move forward. We anticipate that well thought -out proposals emanating from our CHIP working groups to address our region's needs stand a good chance of receiving funding to enable their implementation. This fu nding could be from federal and state resources, foundations, as well as new funding available to our communities for community health improvement via the Determin ation of Need funding mechanism administered by the Massachusetts Department of Public Health . The transition from the issuing of this report to the formation of working groups that are designing strategies to address priority concerns requires that we create a structure and processes that can support our efforts over the next several years. To that end, throughout 2019 and 2020 we will work together to create a sustainable foundation for meeting, decision -making and tracking our work. Based on the robust participation of all parties over the past year, we look forward optimistically to ongoing collaboration that will have measurable, positive impacts on the health and quality of life of residents of our three communities. Analysis As mentioned, in order to collect a robust and comprehensive sample of survey respondents, surveys were avail able in multiple languages. The majority of participants took the English survey (92%), followed by the Spanish survey (7.40%), Portuguese survey (0.38%) and the Arabic survey (0.22%). Due to the low response rate of the Portuguese and Arabic surveys, they were re -translated to English using Survey Monkey. However, because over 100 surveys were completed in Spanish, they were translated to English using R. Though data analysis primarily focused on calculating the frequencies of responses per question, it was essential to ensure that the correct denominators were utilized. For most questions, the denominator calculated was based on the total number of individuals who responded to that particular question. However, when questions contained phrases such as "S elect all that apply" or other phrases directing respondents to select multiple choices, the statistical software SAS was used to determine how many individuals responded to these sets of questions. The denominator then became the total number of people wh o selected at least one response. Assuring that the correct denominators were used in the overall and stratified results ensures that our frequencies are as accurate and precise as possible. Since the survey was available to anyone who lived or worked in Chelsea, Revere or Winthrop, some analyses were done that solely focused on how residents of these communities responded. Residents were defined as those who responded that they either lived or lived and work in either Chelsea, Revere or Winthrop. The Data Analysis Subcommittee determined that the survey respondents who were foreign -born were a population of interest. The foreign -born population was defined as those who were residents (live , or live and work in community) and those who responded that they have lived in the United States within these parameters: "Less than one year," "one to three years," "four to six years," or "more than six years, but not my whole life." Those who responded that they have lived in the United States for their whole lives were defined as "non -foreign born" survey respondents. Youth were defined as those who responded that they were under 18 years old and seniors were defined as those who responded that they were 65 years old or older. While cleaning the data, the analyst found an interesting pattern that echoed changing reactions to choices offered U.S. Census respondents regarding race and ethnicity . Individuals who identified as Hispanic/Latino grappled to respond what race they identified as. The question pertaining to race came before the question asking whether individuals identified as Hispanic/Latino. 116 survey respondents selected "other" as their race and wrote in a response that indicated that they were of Hispanic/Latino descent. One individual even wrote "Why i sn't Hispanic/Latino an option?" North Suffolk 2019 Integrated Community Health Needs Assessment 44 Qualitative Themes The following themes related to community strengths, barriers to accessing services and resources, and top health concerns were found across multiple focus groups and key informant interviews in Che lsea, Revere, and Winthrop. The breakdown of themes within these categories provides insight into how residents and stakeholders view the health of their communities, and what improvements could be made to strengthen community health. Some people expressed positive and negative views on the same issues , based on their own experiences . Although this might seem conflicting, we mention both opposing views to give voice to the experiences of the residents. While some themes are applicable to all three communiti es, or two out of three communities, there are a few themes that were only applicable to Winthrop; this distinction is noted below where appropriate. Community Strengths Resilience was mentioned several times as a strength in Chelsea and Revere. Parti cipants in both communities reported that the populations they work with or are a part of are strong willed and have a desire to access services to improve, despite all of the adversity they have faced. One participant in a staff focus group stated, "Despi te the lack of access to resources, they do their best to try to receive help." Key informants and focus group participants stated that patients often advocate for themselves to try to obtain useful resources. In addition, a focus group participant from Re vere stated, "It is a resilient city that overcomes its obstacles and perseveres." In addition, participants mentioned that there is a strong sense of community pride in Chelsea. Thus, it is evident that focus group participants and key informants believe that the people in these communities are key assets. Diverse populations in both Chelsea and Revere . Multiple focus group participants readily and repeatedly talked about the rich diversity of people in Chelsea and Revere and the increase of ethnic and c ultural groups without a lot of racial tension. According to one focus group participant in Chelsea regarding diversity, "...We are an immigrant city, you get to know about different people and make friends. I belong to a lot of groups." Additionally, one fo cus group participant in Chelsea stated, "I don't feel that, when I walk in Chelsea, people will judge me because of who I am". Many participants also talked about the wide range of restaurants representing a vast array of cultures in their communities, an advantage that other communities do not have. Participants across focus groups reported a desire to create more cultural events and ways to celebrate the diversity in Chelsea and Revere by uniting all of the different ethnic and racial groups so they are not separated in their own groups. Ultimately, participants really embrace this distinct quality of Chelsea and Revere. Physical location and proximity to Boston is a strength for all three communities. Focus group participants and key informants across multiple populations discussed the benefit of being so close to Boston to access services and care. The physical location of these communities was a highlight for many focus group participants in particular. Participants also highlighted the proximity of s ervices within Chelsea, such as schools, the food pantry at St. Luke's Episcopal Church, and services at MGH Chelsea including the food pantry. The beach is a strength in both Revere and Winthrop. Multiple focus group participants stated that the beach in Winthrop is beautiful, and that the beach in Revere helps to bring the community together. One youth participant stated, "There are people from other cities that come to the beach; you get to learn about other people's cultures and it exposes us to diff erent things that people in other cities that are predominantly White don't get". It is apparent that the beach not only aesthetically enhances Revere and Winthrop; it also serves as a common meeting place for people both inside and outside of these commun ities. North Suffolk 2019 Integrated Community Health Needs Assessment 45 Barriers to Accessing Resources and Services Fear around immigration status and the current political administration has created barriers to utilizing public benefits. Multiple focus group participants and key informants reported that many immig rants are afraid of the current political administration and discussed how this has stopped patients from accessing services such as SNAP benefits because they do not want their participation to affect their status in the country. Participants stated that people are generally afraid of the system and do not feel safe accessing resources; some key informants reported an increase in the number of families who have dropped out of social services due to fear and mistrust. Insurance is a barrier for many patie nts, especially immigrants. A couple of key informants and focus group participants stated that it is difficult for immigrants to access medical and mental health services in Chelsea and Revere. A lot of the care that one receives is based on insurance tha t is unfortunately difficult to obtain. In addition, focus group participants mentioned that insurance payments are too high, especially for people who do not bring in a lot of income. Participants shared that it is difficult to access dental care because insurance is not affordable. Thus, some families do not carry insurance, which limits or hinders the ability to access health care. According to one key informant, children may have insurance but their parents may not. Key informants also mentioned that in surance may not cover all necessary costs and medicine that patients need so they go without care due to lack of finances and coverage. Lastly, participants in all three communities mentioned that some hospitals and clinics may not take certain insurance p lans, creating an obstacle to receiving affordable care. Language barriers between providers and patients makes it difficult to provide care. Many key informants and focus group participants touched on the idea that language barriers play a large role in preventing individuals from accessing services. Several key informant interviews showed that providers who do not speak another language or the language their clients/patients speak find it challenging to work with diverse populations, as this limits the assistance and information they can provide. A few key informants reported that providers often assume a certain level of English and literacy among residents but this is more problematic than helpful. One focus group participant mentioned there was a lack of Spanish interpreters in schools, which creates a barrier for Spanish -speaking parents when trying to communicate with teachers. In addition, key informants highlighted how the inability to speak a client or population's language also negatively affects people's perceptions; one key informant in Chelsea stated, "If we can't speak your language, that creates some problems". Lastly, key informants mentioned the need for more ESL classes that are affordable and convenient for community residents; this may h elp build more capacity among residents and begin to alleviate some of the language barriers. Discrimination and lack of cultural sensitivity has led to unfair treatment in Chelsea and Revere. A couple of focus group participants stated they have experie nced discrimination based on language barriers and cultural identity, while other participants talked about receiving unfair treatment because they are in recovery. Elders in Chelsea mentioned that people in the community do not support Hispanics. A couple of participants mentioned that there is a lack of "immigrant friendly" people in Chelsea. In addition, a few focus group participants mentioned they felt discriminated against when it comes to housing and landlords in the city. Participants also stated th ey experienced unfair treatment because they speak languages other than English. This finding is particularly striking because cultural diversity is viewed as a strength in these communities, yet unfair treatment based on culture and language is apparent. Key informants talked about the importance of organizations having staff that are culturally competent to work with different ethnic communities, especially among Spanish - speaking populations. Lastly, focus group participants and one key informant reported that some community members in Revere make comments on social media that are hurtful and thus negatively impact the cohesion of the community. North Suffolk 2019 Integrated Community Health Needs Assessment 46 Social isolation and loneliness is high among elder and Muslim populations. Key informants reported that Musli ms often stay in their own group and are isolated from the larger community; according to one key informant, there is sometimes a perceived "conflict between how to be a good Muslim and a good American at the same time. Showing cultural competence is impor tant. In the schools' calendar planning during Ramadan, sometimes the schools don't even think about that. In any institution, you should have people from the ethnic communities be part of the planning team." In addition, key informants stated that elders choose to be alone; they live alone without company. This may lead to unaddressed health risks and affects how residents work with others to access care. Chelsea could do a better job of messaging to be inclusive and welcoming of its LGBTQ residents. Key informants offered observations and suggestions. "For example, Chelsea could include and invite LGBTQ people in Get Fit programs and walking campaigns and increase awareness among school guidance counselors about our community. Also, some of our immigrant residents are from countries that have unaccepting attitudes towards LGBT issues, yet their families will have LGBT members who may have difficulties at home because of this. City leaders could talk with us about some scenarios regarding LGBTQ people and h ow to better interact with them. Maybe have occasional discussions on Chelsea Access TV. Also, the religious component of some of the street outreach services can be unwelcoming to LGBT people and there is a huge proportion of people who are LGBTQ who are on the street because of their sexual orientation." Housing Rising housing costs and gentrification are a burden on families, especially for people from low -income households. Most focus group participants and key informants across a variety of populat ions in Chelsea and Revere reported that current housing conditions have led to stress for individuals and families. High rental prices and poor housing conditions create a cycle that affects multiple areas of life; for example, one young focus group parti cipant said that if the housing situation was better and people could spend more time at home rather than working to afford their housing, they would be able to spend more time meal prepping, eating healthier foods, and connecting with the community. In ad dition, necessary repairs never seem to be completed; participants mentioned they have broken doors and that landlords do not fix apartments. In addition, participants reported that gentrification is pushing people out, which threatens the closeness of the community as well as the multicultural diversity. One youth focus group participant said, "They are raising the price, kicking us out, and getting rid of the things we love." A key informant who works with parents and young children said, "Gentrification is happening in Chelsea, so people are moving more. Students are moving out of the district. Otherwise, it's the same population with the same needs but the cost of living is going up, so people are struggling more to make ends meet." Participants and key informants reported that a lack of affordable housing has increased the homeless population. Furthermore, the increase in rent and housing costs has led to overcrowded conditions, as people are doubling and tripling up in apartments because they cannot aff ord to live alone or pay for extra rooms. According to participants, upfront costs associated with renting an apartment are too expensive, which is a barrier to accessing affordable housing. Participants also highlighted a disconnect between the income res idents are bringing in and the costs of rent; one participant stated, "You work harder to have a little extra income but the more money you make, the more you have to pay"; thus, even working two and three jobs does not provide the opportunity to easily ke ep up with rising housing costs, demonstrating a clear connection between employment and housing affordability. A key informant on the needs of formerly incarcerated people said housing has, by far become the number one issue: "It used to be jobs but now i t's housing, which helps them keep a job or deal with substance use disorder. Guys would actually rather be in jail than outside on the streets, hustling for a place to stay, and it's getting worse." Lastly, elders mentioned the need for more housing that is separate from families with children. Overall, these findings from the focus group and interview data demonstrate how much the lack of affordable, stable housing has negatively impacted these communities; this is especially important because stable hous ing was reported as one of the necessities for creating a healthy community. North Suffolk 2019 Integrated Community Health Needs Assessment 47 Mental Health Mental health, especially untreated mental illness, is a huge concern for youth and adults. Mental health, notably anxiety and depression, was mentioned in a variety of focus groups as a need that has gone unmet across several populations, including people in recovery or current substance users, youth, elders, and veterans, especially due to trauma. Multiple participants reported that people were dealing with a lot of stress and pressure, but oftentimes mental health is not taken seriously. In addition, multiple focus group participants touched on the influence of race and culture on mental health, stating that some races and cultures do not feel that mental hea lth is an issue that affects them -if people are feeling sad, it is something they should just get over -or that it is something that only affects other people; participants stated there is a mentality that exists that "Depression is for White people". Furth ermore, the lack of services to remedy this issue is disheartening; there are not enough resources to adequately address mental health issues, but there is a long waiting list to access services. One focus group participant mentioned that wait times are lo ng for patients to receive care, so much so that people will proclaim they are going to commit suicide to quickly get care; this participant stated, "No one should have to say 'I'm going to kill myself' in order to get some service". Across all focus group s and multiple key informant interviews, participants stated that more mental health services were necessary, especially more social workers and mental health counselors in schools. Participants also stated that self -care is important for populations deali ng with stress for a variety of reasons, especially to ensure that people can take care of their families. Regarding formerly incarcerated residents, a key informant suggested that "Mental Health First Aid should be taught not just to first responders, but to the people themselves, i.e. the former inmates. It should even be taught to the corrections officers because the CO's have a high suicide rate!" As mental health needs continue to increase among a variety of populations, it is apparent that an increase in mental health services and providers would be highly beneficial. Stigma is a large barrier to accessing services for mental health and treatment for substance use. Focus group participants and key informants in Winthrop reported stereotyping as a pre ssing health concern. One participant stated, "Once you've been labeled, you can't get away from this label (even if it's wrong)". In addition, another participant in Winthrop stated, "We do have a high alcohol use problem that is worse among adults, but i t's hard for people to accept their own problems". Participants in multiple focus groups highlighted the existence of a "not in my neighborhood" or "not in my backyard" mentality among community residents, where people will keep their battles with addictio n and substance use to themselves because they do not want others to know about it due to negative perception. Additionally, a few focus group participants talked about the stigma attached to people in recovery, and how this often leads to discrimination a nd unfair treatment when trying to get a job or access education. There is a need for more services for people in recovery; participants suggested creating a Recovery Community Center that provides resources and education to show support for those in recov ery. Participants and key informants reported that stigma poses a barrier for people to access care for mental health services, stating that shame, guilt, and fear prevent those who are using substances from seeking treatment, support, and services; this i n turn "stops people from living their lives". Access to Healthy and Affordable Foods There are too many fast food restaurants, and too few opportunities to access healthy, affordable foods. Many focus group participants and key informants touched upon rising obesity rates in Chelsea and Revere, especially because of easy access to fast food restaurants. Participants mentioned people turn to fast food restaurants when they are hungry because the food is cheaper and the portions are larger; this particul arly helps when trying to feed a family that is on a budget or tight with money, highlighting the presence of food insecurity. This finding was present in a wide variety of populations, notably among multicultural populations. One youth participant in Chel sea stated, "But there is a lot of fast food places. Every corner, you can find a McDonalds and North Suffolk 2019 Integrated Community Health Needs Assessment 48 Dunkin Donuts". Another youth participant stated, "There's like ten Dunkin Donuts in Chelsea for no reason. It's not even two miles long. We only need like two or three in there, but every corner, there's fast food". Across multiple focus groups, healthy food was deemed more expensive, and participants stressed the importance of providing more access to farmer's markets and organic foods; when participants were a sked what would make a healthy community, all of them mentioned eating healthy foods and vegetables. This finding is especially important because there are limited grocery stores in Chelsea. Similarly, Winthrop focus group participants mentioned the lack o f grocery stores that provide access to healthy foods, as there is only one grocery store in town that is expensive and has a limited variety. In addition to discussing the need to access healthier foods, a couple of focus group participants mentioned that learning healthy eating habits as well, not just eating vegetables and dieting, was important to improve the health of the community. Physical Activity and Recreation There is a need for more activities and opportunities to move around, especially amo ng older youth, in all three communities. While discussing rising obesity rates, multiple focus group participants reported there is a lack of activities and opportunities for people to move around in the community; participants noted there were limited af fordable opportunities to engage in exercise, sports and recreation programs, as well as a lack of walking trails and outdoor bike paths. Youth focus group participants said having more activities in the community would provide a positive outlet for youth to help them avoid turning to alcohol or drugs because they are bored and have nothing to do. One Winthrop focus group participant mentioned there are a lot of parties happening because there is "Not a lot to do in this town for teenagers; once you hit tee n years it's mainly parties", and "There being nothing to do adds to the party culture". In addition, youth participants and a few key informants stated that creating more activities for the community, especially for youth, would encourage participants to be more active rather than sedentary, and promote more interaction with others in the community, especially to unite young people together. This finding is especially important because youth focus group participants stated they spend between 2 to 8 hours p er day interacting with their cell phones and viewing screens. One youth focus group participant in Revere mentioned that youth are "Not pushed to be active in the summer". Focus group participants highlighted the need for more activities for older youth a nd teenagers in particular, as many participants reported there were plenty of opportunities for children. Focus group participants, particularly youth respondents, in Revere and Winthrop stated that a local YMCA would help them stay active. A key informan t from the Muslim community reported that Moroccan youth in Revere who would like to play soccer don't feel welcomed by a soccer league in the city. Focus group participants also mentioned that there are too many hotels in Chelsea, stating that the space c ould be put to greater use in the community. In addition, more green and outdoor spaces would be welcomed in all three of these communities to promote physical activity. Substance Use Substance use remains a pervasive issue in Chelsea, Revere, and Wint hrop and affects multiple areas of residents' lives. Many key informants and focus group participants mentioned the negative impact of substance use across multiple populations. Participants and key informants stated that many people are using substances to self -medicate. Alcohol and heroin were mentioned as substances used by adults in Winthrop. One participant in Winthrop stated, "We're surrounded by yacht clubs, there's drinking everywhere -we can't do a function without alcohol." Marijuana use and vaping , particularly the JUUL, were mentioned as concerns among youth across all three communities. Youth participants mentioned that vaping is prevalent among young people, and this is especially problematic because it can be used in front of teachers in school . One young person in a focus group in Revere mentioned that she saw a student who took a hit from a JUUL in class while the teacher was looking at him; he easily hid the JUUL in his sweatshirt. Another young person in Chelsea stated, "The other day, I wal ked around and saw a 10 -year -old vaping. You see the middle schoolers vaping before school. It is easy to get them". According to focus group participants, youth do not perceive the JUUL as harmful or addictive and it seems like everyone is doing it. This low perception of harm also applies to marijuana; one focus group North Suffolk 2019 Integrated Community Health Needs Assessment 49 participant in Revere stated, "Since marijuana has been legalized, the youth have been using it more. Sometimes, I have found youth using marijuana treating it like a game, like it's fun..." P articipants and key informants stated that more services overall are needed to address addiction and substance use in all three communities. Community residents hide issues related to substance use and addiction in Winthrop and Revere. Multiple focus gro up participants and key informants stated that people in the community are often not open about substance use and will keep it a secret from their neighbors. This finding was especially applicable in Winthrop because it is perceived as a small community, w hich participants stated is a double -edged sword because "Everyone knows everyone's business". This is also related to the presence of stigma that many participants mentioned in multiple focus groups. Participants mentioned they see needles or know of peop le's family members that have used substances, although people will not admit it because they are ashamed and want to keep the issue to themselves. Similarly, youth in Revere mentioned that people do not want to get help for substance use: "Instead of gett ing help, they just hide it until it becomes a larger issue, and then it just creates more problems". Safety Mixed perceptions of safety in Chelsea and Revere. A few focus group participants mentioned that there are areas in Chelsea and Revere that man y people perceive as unsafe, but stated that they do in fact feel safe; a couple of elder focus group participants stated that Chelsea feels a lot safer now than it did before. However, one young focus group participant, a Chelsea resident, mentioned that her car had been broken into three times, causing her to feel unsafe in her neighborhood. In addition, when asked if they feel safe in their community, one participant said no because of racism, community violence such as shootings, and bad traffic; focus group participants were worried about safety after seeing needles in the park and knowing that people are overdosing. One participant in Revere mentioned that is was not safe around Bell Circle due to traffic and the lack of crossing guards. However, in an other resident focus group in Revere, participants stated they feel very safe where they live. A few Spanish speaking focus group participants in Revere mentioned they felt safe while walking down the street and on the bus. Participants also said they want the community to be safer in the future, especially regarding immigrants. Key informants mentioned a change in the perception of Chelsea and Revere being unsafe with high crime rates from the past but it is evident that some of those perceptions still exi st today; while this may be specific to certain areas of Chelsea and Revere, this finding should be explored further. Transportation Transportation was mentioned as both a strength and a challenge to accessing health and social services. Although Chel sea focus group participants noted that access to transportation, especially the 111 bus and the Silver Line, was a strength in Chelsea, participants also stated that transportation was a burden because buses are crowded and do not run frequently enough. W inthrop focus group participants mentioned there is a lack of public transportation, with only one bus running through Winthrop infrequently, making it difficult to access health services. One focus group participant in Winthrop talked about the lack of me dical services in town, and the need to travel into Boston to get care, especially specialized care, which means "Parking, money, traffic, time, and people don't have it." Elders also mentioned that the MBTA RIDE needs to improve since many people rely on it to access services but people end up waiting for it for a long time. In addition, the roads were mentioned as an obstacle to getting around Chelsea and commuting to Boston. Many participants in Revere reported satisfaction with transportation in the cit y; participants mentioned that there is plenty of access to transportation with the blue line and several buses that run frequently. In addition, participants stated that the MGH Shuttle in Revere is more helpful for getting to appointments than the T. Thu s, the availability of transportation in most of the communities is appreciated, but the logistics and execution of the various modes of transportation are not always helpful to community residents. North Suffolk 2019 Integrated Community Health Needs Assessment 50 Environment The streets in Chelsea and Revere need to be cleaned up. Participants stated there was too much trash in Chelsea; they mentioned they see people throw trash on the streets and feel that Broadway is really dirty. One participant stated, "You do not feel good about where you live if there's trash everywhere". Participants in Revere also mentioned that they often see dog mess on the streets. In addition, there are large rats in Revere and Chelsea. One participant stated, "If you're a normal sized rat, that's okay but when you're as big as my face, that's an issue". In addition, one young participant mentioned that she has seen needles on the ground while commuting to school with her mom. When asked what would make a healthy community, a clean environment with clean air and water without trash on the ground was mentioned in several focus groups. The importance of maintaining a clean environment without trash on the ground was prevalent throughout multiple focus groups. The condition of the environment has made a large, negative impact on health, esp ecially in Chelsea and Winthrop. Participants mentioned traffic, air pollution and noise from the airport, and coastal flooding as environmental issues, especially in Winthrop. Because of the airport, insomnia is an issue for residents. In addition, partic ipants mentioned other diseases and conditions that affect the community, such as diabetes, high blood pressure, and cancer. Focus group participants and key informants stated they have noticed higher rates of breast cancer. In addition, residents have dea lt with COPD, respiratory diseases, and asthma due to obesity, as well as poor environmental and industrial conditions; these concerns were mentioned in all three communities. One focus group participant in Winthrop stated, "We've buried a lot of people in their 40s and 50s that wasn't related to substance use", referring to the number of deaths in Winthrop because of environmental cancers and diseases. Implications for Moving Forward Need for stronger collaboration and cohesion among services and organ izations. While multiple focus group participants commented on the strength of community organizations and stakeholders coming together, especially in Chelsea, participants also stated that it would be in everyone's best interest to strengthen cohesion amo ng these stakeholders. Key informants talked about the importance of capitalizing on individuals who are invested and care about these communities to help improve them; working together was mentioned as an important factor in creating a healthy community. Many key informants talked about the importance of increasing communication and sharing more information with providers and networks to better connect services so that everyone is on the same page. One key informant said there a lot of organizations in Che lsea already working on improving the city but she was not sure how well they are working together: "If we're all taking care of the community together, we should all have communication between each other". A few key informants mentioned that there are man y service providers in the community, especially Chelsea, that are all helpful but it would be better for everyone to work together to fully treat community residents. Multiple participants across Chelsea, Revere, and Winthrop, mentioned that it is imperat ive to come together to find common ground and work in the best interests of the community to create a more comprehensive system for holistic care, which would help improve the lack of communication among providers. A couple of focus group participants men tioned that more leadership accountability and buy -in, and leaders who educate themselves on issues in the community, would be advantageous. Lastly, several focus group participants mentioned the need for more community engagement and participation among r esidents of all ages to better unite and enhance these communities. Resistance to change has hindered progress in Winthrop. Several focus group participants stated that people seem to be stuck in their ways and do not readily accept change. Participants also mentioned that people are complacent in Winthrop and resist new people or new things. It is evident that participants hope Winthrop will overcome division and come together to resolve issues to improve the community. North Suffolk 2019 Integrated Community Health Needs Assessment 51 Need to be more proactive than r eactive in Winthrop. Focus group participants mentioned that the community is very supportive when something tragic happens, such as an illness or tragedy, but when it comes to making change ahead of time, this usually does not happen. Oftentimes, resident s react to issues as they come up but participants feel it would be beneficial to have a more proactive role. One participant stated, "It's a pretty responsive community in general; people try to stay in tune with what's going on in town. They care deeply about what happens in the town, but it's also a negative because we're not as proactive -it's a double -edged sword. It would be nice to be a little more proactive". Additional Implications All focus groups and key informant interviews touched upon the n eed for money and consistent, sustainable funding streams to make lasting change, continue vital programming, and expand services for community residents. Winthrop focus group participants in particular stated that new industry and updated infrastructure within the community would help bring in revenue and improve finances to address community needs that are often not viewed the same as surrounding communities such as Chelsea and Revere. In addition, multiple participants across all three communities advoca ted for more resources and funding for schools, a crucial step towards making important improvements in these communities. All in all, sustainable, dependable funding is required to expand services and create imperative changes in Chelsea, Revere, and Wint hrop. The iCHNA ProcessA CHNA is an organized process led b y community partners from healthcare, community-based organizations, social services, residents, and city leaders. These partners work together to identify the top strengths, challenges, and public health needs of a community . Factors that affect both individual and a specific group' s health and well- being were an important part of the iCHNA process. These factors, called the social determinants of health , are things lik e education, income, and housing. They are the conditions into which we are born and r aised, live and work. childhood e xperienceseducationhousing community healthcar e emplo yment income 1,819 Quality of Life Surveys CollectedThe community partners that formed the North Suffolk Integr ated Community Health Needs Assessment (iCHNA) collected and reviewed information from residents, lik e you, and experts living and working in Chelsea, Revere, and Winthrop. For more information, go to our website: Northsuffolkassessment.org Public Health Data22 Focus Groups29 Key Interviews The information gathered during the CHNA is used to create an action plan, called a Community Health Improvement Plan (CHIP). The CHIP explains how community partners and residents can work together to improve the health and well-being for everyone . Over 2,000 people helped to collect and analyze the data.
